Fire protection measures at the facility are supported by an Early Suppression Fast Response (ESFR) automatic sprinkler system.

7.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The facility continues to report and investigate all incidents, including near-misses where there was no property damage or injury.  In addition to existing notifications to employees about all incidents, the facility is developing a monthly Accident Alert and Safety Talk program to further constructively engage employees in accident prevention.  In addition to standard safety training, a monthly topic, relevant to the facility's operations or to an incident within BIC Group will be prepared by the Manager, Environment and Safety and then presented by the front-line supervisor or lead to all facility personnel in small conversational groups of 15 persons or less.  The group will discuss the topic and brainstorm various Human Element, Organizational or Technical measures which could prevent or mitigate a similar situation.

The incoming pallets are placed into rack storage. As work orders are received, individual pallets of lighters are transferred via forklift briefly to the temporary holding area of the facility, where materials are staged for the shift's activities. From this location, the pallets are again transferred via forklift to the packaging area. Lighters are unpackaged, then repackaged per individual customer demands.   After the appropriate consumer packaging is applied, the lighters are repackaged into cases.  The cases are re-palletized and then shipped via trucks/trailers to BIC Group's distribution warehouses. 

The facility is regulated under the Program 1 requirements under the applicability criteria of 40 CFR §68.10, which means that there are no off-site consequences from the handling and storage of isobutane.  

The lighter itself is the gas container. The lighter device is made of engineering-grade plastics and metal, designed to withstand high pressures and physical damage. The gas is in the form of a liquified isobutane gas, or LPG. There are several sizes of lighters and the largest contains less than 5 grams of gas.  The reasonable scenarios for a gas release are the physical crushing of a lighter during handling or during automated packaging.  If a lighter is crushed, the LPG isobutane rapidly escapes from the lighter, expands quickly and typically dissipates to non-flammable levels a few feet from the release point.  Because of the small amount of gas in each container, nearly 95 lighters would have to be crushed simultaneously to produce one pound of gas - the minimum amount of gas necessary to evaluate for an off-site consequence per the RMP regulation.  Breaking 95 lighters simultaneously is not a realistic scenario for this site.  In any case, there is absolutely no reasonable scenario tha

t could result in an explosive impact that extends off site.

3.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at This Facility

BIC Group maintains an overall Environmental, Health, and Safety policy which commits BIC to pollution prevention; risk prevention; regulatory compliance; continuous improvement; and awareness and involvement. The facility develops and implements programs in support of these Group commitments, including programs for accidental release prevention and emergency response.  Environmental and Safety programs are managed by a full time Manager, Environment and Safety who directly serves the BIC Charlotte, NC facilities. The Manager, Environment and Safety works with facility staff to administer several programs which contribute to release prevention including safe work practices, employee training, preventative maintenance and administrative controls designed to ensure that hazards are identified and that safety issues are identified and addressed.

4.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Prevention of accidental releases at the facility is accomplished through compliance with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention provisions; compliance with federal and state environmental, safety, packaging and shipping regulations; and, the application of longstanding corporate philosophies and initiatives which help support safe operations. The following are a few of the examples of the prevention measures which are relevant to this facility:

a.	BIC Group performs extensive in-line quality testing of every individual lighter produced which not only guarantees safe and reliable operation of the product by the consumer, but also provides an additional measure of safety for all storage and warehousing operations.  This facility handles, stores and transports only BiC ® Lighters.
b.	BIC Group specifically designs and tests its packaging for lighters to minimize damage to both the packa

ging and the lighter during handling, storage and transportation and to prevent the accidental release and accumulation of gas.
c.	The facility trains, tests and certifies all fork truck operators, even those with previous certifications and experience.
d.	The facility employs various policies and procedures to limit the height of lighter storage and to eliminate spill hazards from the racks.
e.	The facility conducts many regular inspections including the following: weekly inspections of hazardous waste storage areas, monthly fire extinguisher inspections, and weekly sprinkler control valve and PIV inspection.  Is addition, the  landlord conducts others tests and inspections of the sprinkler and alarm systems required by fire code.
f.	The facility is audited regularly for risk reduction opportunities by its insurance carrier.
g.	The facility conducts regular safety training. 
h.	The facility requires reporting, documenting and investigating all incidents, including near misses in order to fully understand incident causes and to prevent re-occurrence or the occurrence of similar incidents.

5.	Five-Year Accident History

There have been zero accidental releases of isobutane with off-site consequences in the past five years.

6.	Emergency Response Program

BIC has implemented a written Emergency Action and Contingency Plan, which has been prepared in accordance with the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.38, and other regulations including 40 CFR Part 265 Subpart D. This plan establishes detailed facility evacuation, response, and reporting procedures for potential emergencies including fires, explosions, accidental releases, power failures, natural disasters, bomb threats, civil disturbances, and medical emergencies. The plan designates primary and secondary Facility Emergency Coordinators who are responsible for implementing the plan during an emergency.
